verses.text: Therefore, since we have been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Paul connects justification by faith with receiving peace—meaning reconciliation—with God. The phrase 'through our Lord Jesus Christ' centers faith and peace in Christ's unique mediating work (see 1 Tim. 2:5). The original language carefully suggests a completed action leading to an ongoing result, conveying firmness in our standing.

verses.text: Through him we have also obtained access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
verses.comment: The idea of 'access' recalls the Old Testament’s temple imagery (see Ps. 24:3), now fulfilled in Christ who opens the way for believers to share in God's presence and grace, leading toward participation in his glory.

verses.text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance,
verses.comment: Paul points to the spiritual value of suffering. It has the effect of refining believers (cf. 1 Pet. 1:6–7). The progression from suffering to endurance emphasizes growth in virtue through life's trials.

verses.text: and endurance produces character, and character produces hope.
verses.comment: True hope is the fruit of tested character, not mere wishful thinking. Salvation involves transformation—an ongoing process of renewal (cf. Rom. 12:2).

verses.text: And hope does not disappoint us, because God’s love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who has been given to us.
verses.comment: The gift of the Holy Spirit is the assurance and source of God's love within believers. The image of 'poured into our hearts' echoes Old Testament promises about God’s Spirit (see Ezek. 36:27), signifying a lived and transformative experience beyond legal standing.

verses.text: For while we were still weak, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
verses.comment: The timing and purposefulness of Christ's death demonstrates God’s providence and mercy, acting for those powerless to save themselves, anticipating themes of divine initiative in salvation.

verses.text: For one will scarcely die for a righteous person—though perhaps for a good person someone might even dare to die—
verses.comment: Paul contrasts human love, which is limited, with divine love. Even noble self-sacrifice has its limits among humans.

verses.text: but God shows his own love for us in this: while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
verses.comment: The phrase 'while we were still sinners' underscores the unmerited nature of divine grace. Christ’s death is the ultimate demonstration of love, fulfilling Old Testament imagery of the suffering servant (cf. Isa. 53:5–6).

verses.text: Much more then, since we have now been justified by his blood, shall we be saved by him from the wrath.
verses.comment: ‘Blood’ refers directly to Christ's sacrificial death, seen as the means of atonement and justification. The passage hints at salvation as an ongoing process, culminating in full deliverance from God’s judgment.

verses.text: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, much more, now that we have been reconciled, shall we be saved by his life.
verses.comment: Reconciliation comes through the death of Christ; full salvation comes through his risen life. Paul emphasizes salvation as both a completed action and an ongoing transformation (see Rom. 8:24).

verses.text: Not only that, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received reconciliation.
verses.comment: The joy believers experience is rooted in the reality of reconciliation, which Christ accomplished. Restoration to friendship with God stands at the heart of the gospel.

verses.text: Therefore, just as sin came into the world through one man, and death through sin, so death spread to all men because all sinned—
verses.comment: Paul begins the comparison between Adam and Christ. The idea that all share in Adam's sin underscores human need for redemption, pivotal for later doctrines of original sin and inherited fallen nature.

verses.text: for sin was indeed in the world before the law was given, but sin is not counted where there is no law.
verses.comment: Even before the giving of the Mosaic Law, sin existed and resulted in death, highlighting that the root problem goes beyond the Law to the human condition.

verses.text: Nevertheless, death reigned from Adam until Moses, even over those who did not sin in the likeness of Adam’s transgression, who is a type of the one to come.
verses.comment: Adam is presented as a 'type' or foreshadowing of Christ. Both Adam and Christ function as representatives, each affecting the destiny of humankind, but in opposite ways.

verses.text: But the free gift is not like the trespass. For if many died because of one man's trespass, much more have the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one man, Jesus Christ, abounded for many.
verses.comment: God’s grace vastly surpasses the effects of Adam’s sin. Paul’s use of 'gift' and 'grace' (charis) points to a supernatural favor, not earned by works but received through Christ.

verses.text: And the result of the gift is not like that which came through the one who sinned. For judgment followed one trespass and brought condemnation, but the free gift followed many trespasses and brought justification.
verses.comment: Christ's gift overturns and overcomes not just Adam’s sin but the accumulated sins of humanity, resulting in justification, a central theme in Paul’s gospel.

verses.text: For if, because of the trespass of the one man, death reigned through that one, much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one man, Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: 'Reign in life' suggests both present spiritual life and future glory. Righteousness is Christ’s gift received, not merely a legal status but transformative, restoring the believer fully.

verses.text: So then, as one trespass led to condemnation for all men, so also one act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all men.
verses.comment: Paul draws a sweeping parallel but also distinction between Adam’s disobedience and Christ’s obedience. Universal scope is stressed ('all men'), yet elsewhere Paul clarifies the necessity of faith and reception.

verses.text: For as by the one man's disobedience the many were made sinners, so by the one man's obedience the many will be made righteous.
verses.comment: 'Obedience' here points to Christ's entire saving work—including his faithfulness to the cross (see Isa. 53:11). Righteousness is the result of being united with Christ.

verses.text: Now the law came in to increase the trespass, but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,
verses.comment: The Law reveals and magnifies sin, making us aware of our need for redemption. Yet God's grace always surpasses human sinfulness.

verses.text: so that, just as sin reigned in death, grace might also reign through righteousness leading to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.comment: Paul presents righteousness as the gift through which grace reigns, resulting in eternal life—a holistic participation in Christ, both now and in the age to come.
